commit_message:
Docs: Fix broken links and make more robust

The following links are broken:
https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/contributor/sourcedoc/backends/djbdns_agent.html
https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/contributor/sourcedoc/backends/gdnsd_agent.html
https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/contributor/sourcedoc/backends/knot2_agent.html

Fix those.

Also, use in some places internal links instead of external ones to
make linking more robust against renames of files.

Change-Id: Ia4724f03e9bba1a6f05a8290b0eb31790ed9c715

subject: Add missing ostree admin init-fs call
messages:
[{'account_id': 21741, 'date': '2017-11-01 08:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2017-11-01 09:44:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20259, 'date': '2017-11-01 15:34:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I couldn't reproduce this error with DIB_RELEASE=25, which is the version magnum tells you to use. If you are using DIB_RELEASE=26, then dib won't be able to find the "docker_host" ref and won't be able to properly pull the tree. Is there any collateral effect of an init-fs when the hierarchy is already there?'}, {'account_id': 21741, 'date': '2017-11-01 19:56:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Adding this line of code works also fine with Fedora 25 - so this might be more future prove. ;-)'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-08-25 20:08:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is not necessary given we have removed the image build scripts. Thanks.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-01 08:22:39.000000000', 'message': 'Add missing ostree admin init-fs call

Currently the 80-fedora-atomic fails with:
    error: opendir(ostree/repo): No such file or directory
The reason is, that the init-fs call is missing which creates
the needed directory hierarchy.

Change-Id: Ibd646e216b75ad069c678d10969f85b7c95b2ca7
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>
'}]
commit_message:
Add missing ostree admin init-fs call

Currently the 80-fedora-atomic fails with:
    error: opendir(ostree/repo): No such file or directory
The reason is, that the init-fs call is missing which creates
the needed directory hierarchy.

Change-Id: Ibd646e216b75ad069c678d10969f85b7c95b2ca7
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

commit_message:
Modify test_pods_api to wait until the pod reaches status "Running"

We wait 1h max because we need to wait for the scheduler to be
running (needs hyperkube container) which can take more than 30mn
in non accelerated VMs, plus the pulling of nginx

Closes-Bug: 1645715
Change-Id: I6468af79c6151a57bacfbda3b11f2ffe2f27d86e

commit_message:
Fix Swarm multi master with LB cluster creation

Swarm cluster that uses ETCD failed with LB and TLS enable.
Fix protocol hardcode

Change-Id: If0222357418e7a9d53ea102d818a0f18ca2d3101
Closes-Bug: #1712054
Closes-Bug: #1679724

commit_message:
Add support for proxy and TLS to functional tests

Functional tests currently only support working with installations
based on devstack, not using TLS encryption on the endpoint, and having
direct connection to Internet. Tests are failing if these conditions
are not fulfilled. To provide a workaround, this commit adds 4 new
settings to functional_creds.conf file:

magnum.cacert - to set CA certificate for TLS endpoint
magnum.http_proxy - passed to http_proxy attribute of test cluster
magnum.https_proxy - passed to https_proxy attribute of test cluster
magnum.no_proxy - passed to no_proxy attribute of test cluster

Swarm test now pings DNS server, configured for a cluster. It defaults
to 8.8.8.8, but can be overridden. This is needed because outcoming
ICMP packets are often forbidden in corporate firewalls, so ping to
public DNS server 8.8.8.8 does not work.

Also, test for number of running services changed to verify that
at least one service is running. Installations other then devstack may
have more then one running conductor.

Change-Id: I0e2951efb2c03dd03ddebc90fe10e11e72430b5f

commit_message:
Support dcos installation on centos bm cluster

This patch provides support for installing dcos on centos using magnum.
A new coe type(dcos) is added. This provides support for baremetal.
Design spec and steps on how to test can be found in
contrib/drivers/dcos_centos_ironic_v1/README.md

Problems:
1. Public agent nodes are not supported now.
2. There are still some bugs when load balancer creation in heat
template.
See https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1635449

Co-Authored-By: vmud213 (vinay50muddu@yahoo.com)
Co-Authored-By: fengbeihong (fengbeihong@gmail.com)

Change-Id: Ib412e183838bf16eed790a0f0112554d1d72e3f9
Partially-Implements: blueprint mesos-dcos

commit_message:
Update api-ref to include the baymodel detail API

Magnum supports a 'detail' API to show the list of baymodel
or cluster templates with details but that is not mentioned
in our API doc.
So this patch updates the api-ref to include the details
of 'detail' API available for both cluster template and
baymodel.

Partial-Bug: #1674314

Change-Id: I06188f9d6e99ffee150f96b8c3782146ac24cee2

commit_message:
Install magnum with packstack

Add a document about installing magnum with packstack.

Change-Id: I65c998eefdf37d7b1082ac8ffbcea7b457f704b4
Implements: blueprint magnum-packstack-install

I am going to propose an alternative approach. Please evaluate the pros and cons of each design and select the better one:

DB Table Structure:

Cluster
 - name
 - uuid
 - Foreign key to Version
 - Other attributes (image, flavor, etc.)

Template
 - name
 - uuid
 - Foreign key to Version
 - Other attributes (image, flavor, etc.)

Version
 - version
 - Other attributes (lockdown by operators)

Create
------

A Version is created:
 - version = 1
 - coe = k8s
 - server_type = vm
 - distro = atomic
 - image = xxx

A Template is created:
 - Sets FK to Version
 - flavor = m1.small
 ...

Create a Template from Version won't copy attributes.
Template cannot override attributes in Version.

A Cluster is created:
 - Sets FK to Version
 - flavor = m1.medium
 ...
Create a Cluster from Template will copy all attributes in the templates.
Cluster can override attributes in Template, but cannot override attributes in Version

Cluster Update
------

Update a Cluster are requested using the UUID of the Cluster.
Users can update the FK to reference a newer Version to upgrade the cluster.
Users can update other attributes (i.e. node_count), but it won't trigger a cluster upgrade.

Template Update
------

Update a Template are requested using the UUID of the Template.
The Version or other attributes can be changed, but the change is only updated in DB.

Version Update
------

Version is immutable so update is not allowed.


Data model impact
-----------------

cluster:
 - id
 - uuid
 - project_id
 - user_id
 - name
 - stack_id
 - status
 - status_reason
 - api_address
 - trust_id
 - trustee_username
 - trustee_user_id
 - trustee_password
 - coe_version
 - container_version
 - ca_cert_ref
 - magnum_cert_ref
 - node_addresses
 - master_addresses
 - cluster_version_id (new)
 - FK to cluster_attributes (new)
cluster_template:
 - id
 - uuid
 - project_id
 - user_id
 - name
 - public
 - cluster_version_id (new)
 - FK to cluster_attributes (new)
cluster_version:
 - id
 - uuid
 - project_id
 - user_id
 - name
 - FK to cluster_attributes (new)
cluster_attributes:
 - id (new)
 - apiserver_port
 - create_timeout
 - discovery_url
 - node_count
 - master_count
 - keypair_id
 - labels
 - external_network_id
 - fixed_network
 - fixed_subnet
 - network_driver
 - volume_driver
 - dns_nameserver
 - coe
 - http_proxy
 - https_proxy
 - no_proxy
 - registry_enabled
 - tls_disabled
 - insecure_registry
 - master_lb_enabled
 - floating_ip_enabled
 - image_id
 - flavor_id
 - docker_volume_size
 - docker_storage_driver
 - cluster_distro
 - server_type
 - master_flavor_id"}, {'account_id': 9995, 'date': '2016-11-17 10:23:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Can you clarify for me?"}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-17 16:43:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

@Ricardo,

The key difference between cluster_version and cluster_template is that:
* Template/Cluster that was created from Version doesn't copy its attributes. Instead, it sets a reference to the version object.
* Cluster that was created from Template copy all its attributes. In addition, it doesn't store a reference to the Template object.

The key goal is to avoid an inconsistent set of attributes that are stored in two places (Cluster and ClusterTemplate). The benefits of introducing another schema is for solving the data consistency issue of this proposal. Here is the logic:
* If attributes are stored in Version, it cannot be stored again in Cluster/ClusterTempalte. All Clusters/ClusterTempaltes are expected to look up the Version foreign key to look up the attribute.
* If attributes are stored in ClusterTemplate, they should not be referenced by Cluster after the cluster has been created. Then, any change in the ClusterTemplate won't cause any data inconsistency issue."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-17 16:52:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> @Ricardo,
 >

 > In addition, it doesn't store a reference to the Template object.
 > 
 > The key goal is to avoid an inconsistent set of attributes that are
 > stored in two places (Cluster and ClusterTemplate). The benefits of
 > introducing another schema is for solving the data consistency
 > issue of this proposal. Here is the logic:
 > * If attributes are stored in Version, it cannot be stored again in
 > Cluster/ClusterTempalte. All Clusters/ClusterTempaltes are expected
 > to look up the Version foreign key to look up the attribute.
 > * If attributes are stored in ClusterTemplate, they should not be
 > referenced by Cluster after the cluster has been created. Then, any
 > change in the ClusterTemplate won't cause any data inconsistency
 > issue.

In the current combination of this spec and the flatten attributes spec, there will never be a Cluster or ClusterTemplate that reference the same attribute entity in the db.  Each create a new attributes entity when they are created.  The ClusterTemplate attributes will be used to create the attributes on a Cluster create but it will be a new attributes entity in the db. Cluster will keep a reference to the template entity that was used to create it so that it can be used for possible future upgrades if the Template is updated to a new version.  I think this already solves the concern that you have."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-17 17:00:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

 > attributes will be used to create the attributes on a Cluster
 > create but it will be a new attributes entity in the db. Cluster
 > will keep a reference to the template entity that was used to

This is the problem. When a cluster is created, it copies all its attributes from a cluster template, but doesn't drop the reference. As a result, there are two ways to act on a cluster:
* modify the attributes in cluster.
* modify the attributes in cluster template.
Then, there will be a data consistency issue because it is hard to sync the set of attributes in cluster and cluster_template.

Why not just drop the reference from cluster to cluster_template if you want to copy all its attributes?

 > create it so that it can be used for possible future upgrades if
 > the Template is updated to a new version.  I think this already
 > solves the concern that you have."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-17 17:14:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

ok, i understand now.

The link is to the ClusterTemplate which now does not contain any of the attributes. It contains a link to the latest set of attributes only.  So modifying a ClusterTemplate that was used to create a Cluster will have no impact on the Cluster. It will just update the ClusterTemplate latest value to point to the new version that is created.  Nothing will happen to the existing Cluster or the Attributes entry in the db that the Cluster created.  At that point the user does have 2 ways to modify the Cluster. 1) cluster-update directly as we allow now.  2) cluster-upgrade that will update the cluster to the latest version of ClusterTemplate that was used to create it.  

Just modifying the ClusterTemplate will create a new version entry in the db but will not change the original template entry or any of the db entries that were created from Clusters that used that version.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-17 18:02:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Again, this is the problem. Let's me give an example:
* There is a cluster template with a set of attributes in state A.
* There is a cluster created from the cluster template. The set of attributes with state A was copied to the cluster.
* There is a cluster-update that modifies the attributes from state A to state B in cluster.
* There is a cluster-upgrade that modifies the attributes from state A to state C in cluster template.

As you saw, the state is diverged. Do we need to sync two set of attributes, with one of them in state B, and another of them in state C?

 > will update the cluster to the latest version of ClusterTemplate
 > that was used to create it.
 > 
 > Just modifying the ClusterTemplate will create a new version entry
 > in the db but will not change the original template entry or any of
 > the db entries that were created from Clusters that used that
 > version."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-17 18:20:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

good example, lets walk through it:

1)There is a cluster template with a set of attributes in state A.

* ClusterTemplate entry is created. 1st version entry is  created.

2)There is a cluster created from the cluster template. The set of attributes with state A was copied to the cluster.

* Cluster is created with a new attributes entry copied from the clustertemplate v1.

3)There is a cluster-update that modifies the attributes from state A to state B in cluster.

* cluster verifies the difference between state A and state B is allowed. It updates the cluster attributes entry and updates the Cluster. It still retains a reference to the ClusterTemplate which is still at v1. This is still valid info since it did come originate from that template. They don't match but there is nothing wrong with that as the user was the one who made the change.

4) The ClusterTemplate is updated to a new version(v2)

* A new version entry is created and the ClusterTemplate is updated to indicate that this new version is the latest. Nothing happens to any of the Clusters that were created from the ClusterTemplate.

5)There is a cluster-upgrade on the Cluster that was created using the v1 version.

* cluster-upgrade will verify that the differences between current version(State B) and the ClusterTemplate(v2) are allowed. If so then the Cluster attributes entry will be updated to match v2 and the Cluster will be updated.  

I think there might be some corner cases here that we need to work out."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-17 18:49:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

OK, let's walk through this again with more a specific example.

1)There is a cluster template with a set of attributes in state A. ClusterTemplate entry is created. 1st version entry is created.
$ magnum cluster-template-create --node-count=1 --coe=atomic_v1 --name=mytemplate # template: node_count=1,coe=atomic_v1

2)There is a cluster created from the cluster template. The set of attributes with state A was copied to the cluster. Cluster is created with a new attributes entry copied from the clustertemplate v1.
$ magnum cluster-create --template=mytemplate --name=mycluster # cluster: node_count=1,coe=atomic_v1

3)There is a cluster-update that modifies the attributes from state A to state B in cluster. Cluster verifies the difference between state A and state B is allowed. It updates the cluster attributes entry and updates the Cluster. It still retains a reference to the ClusterTemplate which is still at v1. This is still valid info since it did come originate from that template. They don't match but there is nothing wrong with that as the user was the one who made the change.
$ magnum cluster-update mycluster --node-count=2 # cluster: node_count=2,coe=atomic_v1

4) The ClusterTemplate is updated to a new version(v2). A new version entry is created and the ClusterTemplate is updated to indicate that this new version is the latest. Nothing happens to any of the Clusters that were created from the ClusterTemplate.
$ magnum cluster-template-update mytemplate --coe=atomic_v2 # template: node_count=1,coe=atomic_v2

5)There is a cluster-upgrade on the Cluster that was created using the v1 version. cluster-upgrade will verify that the differences between current version(State B) and the ClusterTemplate(v2) are allowed. If so then the Cluster attributes entry will be updated to match v2 and the Cluster will be updated.
$ magnum cluster-upgrade mycluster # cluster: node_count=2,coe=atomic_v1 -> node_count=1,coe=atomic_v2

Then, as you suggested, we upgrade the cluster attributes to v2, which is from "node_count=2,coe=atomic_v1" to "node_count=1,coe=atomic_v2". This is not undesirable, because a cluster upgrade basically resets all the attributes (i.e. node_count) and resets the cluster to a factory state. Is it acceptable?'}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-17 19:50:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

This is a great point and one that should be address as part of cluster-upgrade. I think cluster-upgrade should ignore certain attributes.  node_count is a great example of one that should not be modified through a cluster-upgrade. If the user wants to change the node_count is should only be done through cluster(or nodegroup)-update.  

cluster-upgrade should be limited to the attributes that are really an upgrade(coe related attributes). cluster-update is for changes that are cluster specific(node_count, nodegroups, keypairs, etc...) That is the point of having cluster-upgrade in general right? To be able to change things that can't be changed via cluster-update. Otherwise we could just have cluster-update with a flag for update based on template.

So i think solving the problem lies in better defining the difference between an update and an upgrade. I think if we allow them to modify the same things then we will need a much more complicated backend which i'm not sure we really want or need."}, {'account_id': 9995, 'date': '2016-11-17 20:33:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

2)There is a cluster created from the cluster template. The set of attributes with state A was copied to the cluster. Cluster is created with a new attributes entry copied from the clustertemplate v1.

invalid operation: docker_volume_size is locked in template <template-name>
4) The ClusterTemplate is updated to a new version(v2). A new version entry is created and the ClusterTemplate is updated to indicate that this new version is the latest. Nothing happens to any of the Clusters that were created from the ClusterTemplate.

> > One thing to remember is that the list of attributes that can be

 > > cluster-update myCluster --UpdateToLatestTemplate
 > 
 > If two clusters do the update at the same time, it will cause race
 > condition issues.
 > 
 > >
 > > cluster-upgrade is limited to coe_version changes.

Overriding on creation and updating an existing cluster are 2 very different things.  Overriding is changing values before the cluster is created. It is not modifying a db entry at all. It will create the entry with the override values. An update is on an existing cluster and will modify a db entry.

Don't understand the race condition.  Both clusters will have different db entries for attributes.  So there would not be a race condition."}, {'account_id': 9995, 'date': '2016-11-17 21:59:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Here is an example:
* There is a cluster template A with node_count = 0
User A:
* Issues a "cluster-template-list" to select a cluster template with no node (cluster template A is selected)
* Issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
User B:
* Issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
* Issues a "cluster-update" to scale the node_count to 100
Race condition:
* User B issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
* User A issues a "cluster-template-list" to select template A
* User B issues a "cluster-update" to scale the node_count = 100 (with --UpdateToTemplate, template A has 100 nodes now).
* User A issues a "cluster-create" by using template A.
User A expects to create a cluster with 0 node, but he/she actually creates a cluster with 100 nodes.'}, {'account_id': 10206, 'date': '2016-11-18 14:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-18 16:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> Here is an example:
 > * There is a cluster template A with node_count = 0
 > User A:
 > * Issues a "cluster-template-list" to select a cluster template
 > with no node (cluster template A is selected)
 > * Issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
 > User B:
 > * Issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
 > * Issues a "cluster-update" to scale the node_count to 100
 > Race condition:
 > * User B issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
 > * User A issues a "cluster-template-list" to select template A
 > * User B issues a "cluster-update" to scale the node_count = 100
 > (with --UpdateToTemplate, template A has 100 nodes now).
 > * User A issues a "cluster-create" by using template A.
 > User A expects to create a cluster with 0 node, but he/she actually
 > creates a cluster with 100 nodes.


There is no race condition here.  I don't see a cluster-template-update at all.  So the template never changed. A cluster-update only updates the db entry for the cluster not for the clustertemplate. It remains the same and there is no new version yet. So when user B does a --UpdateToTemplate nothing happens as the template has not changed.

If we change this to User B doing a cluster-template-update to change the node_count then they are creating a new ClusterTemplate version and when that happens any further creates will use the latest version.  That is expected behavior and I don't know how we would get around that.  Updating public ClusterTemplates is a serious thing, i'm assuming will only be done by operators.  This is now different then now if someone creates a ClusterTemplate and then changes it. If a user listed it before it was changed and then creates after it was changed this still happens.  At least now we have versions to track that a changed happened in the template.  The user will now at least be able to see that the version changed from when they listed to when they created.'}, {'account_id': 15123, 'date': '2016-11-18 17:00:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

(from @Jaycen)

 > If we change this to User B doing a cluster-template-update to
 > change the node_count then they are creating a new ClusterTemplate
 > version and when that happens any further creates will use the
 > latest version.  That is expected behavior and I don't know how we
 > would get around that.

I tend to agree with this. What if the template was being updated to address a security problem? I would think the operator updating the ClusterTemplate would intend it to be used immediately.

Perhaps we could have the client give a warning that the ClusterTemplate version chosen is extremely new. But only if we find this is really a problem, because I don't don't think that it would be."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-18 20:14:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

 > > * Issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
 > > User B:
 > > * Issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
 > > * Issues a "cluster-update" to scale the node_count to 100
 > > Race condition:
 > > * User B issues a "cluster-create" by using template A
 > > * User A issues a "cluster-template-list" to select template A
 > > * User B issues a "cluster-update" to scale the node_count = 100
 > > (with --UpdateToTemplate, template A has 100 nodes now).
 > > * User A issues a "cluster-create" by using template A.

There are several confusions here:

1. Public templates can only be updated by operators.
This is not true. Currently, anyone can publish a template. In addition, a user can update any template in the tenant, regardless of he/she is a operator is not.

2. Non-public template cannot be shared between users.
This is not true as well. Non-public templates are shared within the tenant. The only difference between public and non-public templates is the visibility across tenants.

3. One way to distinguish public template (created by operators) and non-public template (created by end-users) is to separate these two entities by using different abstractions. For example, on my proposal, I proposed to model a public immutable *template* as Version, and model a non-public mutable *template* as Template. A public immutable *template* is used by admin to do the upgrade, and the non-public mutable *template* is used by end-users to store a set of default parameters.'}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-21 16:34:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> 
 > I am confused about the --UpdateToTemplate option now. By its name,
 > it seems to me that this option is for writing through from cluster
 > to template when there is a cluster-update. However, your latest
 > comment suggested that this option is not. Then, I don't understand
 > what this option is going to do and how it can solve the problem.
 > Please elaborate it further with examples.

The --UpdateToTemplate was just a suggestion I added. It is not even in the spec.  The idea behind it was that if cluster-upgrade was only for coe_version and cluster-update was used to change other attributes of the cluter, the --UpdateToTemplate option would update the values of the cluster to the latest version of the template it was created from. That was just a possible suggestion for another way to use the versioning to update clusters. It is not in the spec and I think it would only be added if needed.

Summary on how db entries are created/updated:

ClusterTemplate 
    * Cluster-Template-Create: creates entry
    * Cluster-Template-Update: Updates latest version attribute
    * Cluster-Template-Delete: Updates deleted attribute
    * db entry is only deleted from db when marked for delete and 
      no Clusters have references to any ClusterTemplateVersion 
      that link to this ClusterTemplate

ClusterTemplateVersion
    * Cluster-Template-Create: creates new db entry
    * Cluster-Template-Update: creates new db entry
    * Cluster-Template-Delete: Deletes any version db entries that
      are not used by any existing Clusters

Cluster db entries are completely different from Template entries. 

cluster-create: creates a new cluster db entry, may reference a clustertemplate entry but the clustertemplate entry is not modified in the process even if overrides are used. The overrided attributes will be present in the cluster db entry, but the clustertemplate entry will not be modified.

cluster-update: only changes cluster db entry values. A clustertemplate entry may be referenced as a source for the changes but only the cluster db entry will be modified.

cluster-upgrade: only changes cluster db entry values. A clustertemplate entry may be referenced as a source for the changes but only the cluster db entry will be modified."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-21 16:58:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> There are several confusions here:
 > 
 > 1. Public templates can only be updated by operators.
 > This is not true. Currently, anyone can publish a template. In
 > addition, a user can update any template in the tenant, regardless
 > of he/she is a operator is not.
 > 
 > 2. Non-public template cannot be shared between users.
 > This is not true as well. Non-public templates are shared within
 > the tenant. The only difference between public and non-public
 > templates is the visibility across tenants.
 > 
 > 3. One way to distinguish public template (created by operators)
 > and non-public template (created by end-users) is to separate these
 > two entities by using different abstractions. For example, on my
 > proposal, I proposed to model a public immutable *template* as
 > Version, and model a non-public mutable *template* as Template. A
 > public immutable *template* is used by admin to do the upgrade, and
 > the non-public mutable *template* is used by end-users to store a
 > set of default parameters.

Agree with you here that there is some confusion.  I think the point that is that there are common use cases around public templates with how operators will use them.  These are not enforced by Magnum just known use cases.  We are trying to support those use cases without locking down magnum to only work one way.  This first iteration of versioning is to provide functionality that operators are asking for with upgrades and template versioning. 

Here is what I understand those requests are and this spec is trying to fulfill those:

* Operators want to be able to update a current template for their users without having to create a new template or lose a history of who created a cluster pre or post a change.

* Operators want to be able to trigger an upgrade/update of a Cluster from an older version to the latest version.

I can think of other uses for versioning like someone wanting to show only the difference between versions(Mahduri mentioned that). This spec leaves that open for future improvement but doesn't cover beyond the current needs mentioned above.

Here is how this spec covers those requirements:

- ClusterTemplate object that has the reference of the latest version of attributes for the template.

- ClusterTemplateVersion objects for cluster attributes that are immutable and created for each initial template and template update. They all reference the ClusterTemplate object they were created for so they can be a reference as long as needed.  

- Cluster objects have reference to template used to create them and that template entry can't be removed will the cluster exists.

Why complete attribute entries over diff entries for version? This is so when referenced in a cluster there is no need to put together both the initial entry and the current entry. Each entry has everything needed.  When a diff is needed for an upgrade/update it can do a compare with the current cluster values and the latest, instead of having to compare the cluster, initial template, and the diff of the latest template."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-21 20:10:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> > There are several confusions here:
 > >
 > > 1. Public templates can only be updated by operators.
 > > This is not true. Currently, anyone can publish a template. In
 > > addition, a user can update any template in the tenant,
 > regardless
 > > of he/she is a operator is not.
 > >
 > > 2. Non-public template cannot be shared between users.
 > > This is not true as well. Non-public templates are shared within
 > > the tenant. The only difference between public and non-public
 > > templates is the visibility across tenants.
 > >
 > > 3. One way to distinguish public template (created by operators)
 > > and non-public template (created by end-users) is to separate
 > these
 > > two entities by using different abstractions. For example, on my
 > > proposal, I proposed to model a public immutable *template* as
 > > Version, and model a non-public mutable *template* as Template. A
 > > public immutable *template* is used by admin to do the upgrade,
 > and
 > > the non-public mutable *template* is used by end-users to store a
 > > set of default parameters.
 > 
 > Agree with you here that there is some confusion.  I think the
 > point that is that there are common use cases around public
 > templates with how operators will use them.  These are not enforced
 > by Magnum just known use cases.  We are trying to support those use
 > cases without locking down magnum to only work one way.  This first
 > iteration of versioning is to provide functionality that operators
 > are asking for with upgrades and template versioning.
 > 
 > Here is what I understand those requests are and this spec is
 > trying to fulfill those:
 > 
 > * Operators want to be able to update a current template for their
 > users without having to create a new template or lose a history of
 > who created a cluster pre or post a change.
 > 
 > * Operators want to be able to trigger an upgrade/update of a
 > Cluster from an older version to the latest version.
 > 
 > I can think of other uses for versioning like someone wanting to
 > show only the difference between versions(Mahduri mentioned that).
 > This spec leaves that open for future improvement but doesn't cover
 > beyond the current needs mentioned above.
 > 
 > Here is how this spec covers those requirements:
 > 
 > - ClusterTemplate object that has the reference of the latest
 > version of attributes for the template.
 > 
 > - ClusterTemplateVersion objects for cluster attributes that are
 > immutable and created for each initial template and template
 > update. They all reference the ClusterTemplate object they were
 > created for so they can be a reference as long as needed.
 > 
 > - Cluster objects have reference to template used to create them
 > and that template entry can't be removed will the cluster exists.
 > 
 > Why complete attribute entries over diff entries for version? This
 > is so when referenced in a cluster there is no need to put together
 > both the initial entry and the current entry. Each entry has
 > everything needed.  When a diff is needed for an upgrade/update it
 > can do a compare with the current cluster values and the latest,
 > instead of having to compare the cluster, initial template, and the
 > diff of the latest template.

Based on your requirements, I suggest an amendment of the design as following:

1. Introduce the concept of "versioned attributes". Allow operators to label a set of attributes as versioned attributes when they creates a cluster template.

* e.g. magnum cluster-template-create --node-count=1 --coe=atomic_v1 --versioned_attributes=coe

2. The template version is incremented if a versioned attribute is updated, but a update on unversioned attributes won't increment the template version.

* e.g. magnum cluster-template-update coe=atomic_v2 # this increments the template version
* e.g. magnum cluster-template-update node-count=2 # this won't increment the template version

3. If a user create a cluster from a cluster template, only the unversioned attributes are copied over from cluster to cluster. The versioned attributes are not copied over but the cluster store a reference to the template version object. The complete set of attributes of the cluster consists of i) unversioned attributes stored in cluster db, and ii) versioned attributed stored in a template version db.

* magnum cluster-template-create --node-count=1 --coe=atomic_v1 --versioned-attributes=coe
* magnum cluster-create --template=<UUID> # only node_count=1 is copied over, coe=atomic_v1 stays in the template version object.

4. If a user updates a cluster, he/she can only update unversioned attributes. Updating versioned attributes is not allowed in all cases.

* magnum cluster-update --node-count=1 # allow
* magnum cluster-update --coe=atomic_v2 # disallow

5. If a user upgrades a cluster, the reference to the template version is changed (it points to a newer version that stores a newer set of versioned attributes). All the unversioned attributes are unchanged.

* magnum cluster-template-create --node-count=1 --coe=atomic_v1 --versioned-attributes=coe # template v1: node_count=1,coe=atomic_v1
* magnum cluster-create --template=<UUID> # cluster: node_count=1,version=<ID_OF_TEMPLATE_V1>
* magnum cluster-update --node-count=2 # cluster: node_count=2,version=<ID_OF_TEMPLATE_V1>
* magnum cluster-template-update --coe=atomic_v2 # template v2: node_count=1,coe=atomic_v2
* magnum cluster-upgrade # cluster: node_count=2,version=<ID_OF_TEMPLATE_V2>'}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-21 20:28:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

@hongbin

This seems very complicated to me. Why would we break up versioned vs unversioned attributes? This makes extra work for the operator creating the templates.  It also adds a lot more to the api commands. The proposed way doesn't really add any new commands or a lot of extra flags.  It just simply adds versioning through the current commands.  

This suggestion also basically goes back to the way clustertemplate and cluster worked before in that they had different attributes. The new design of Templates in the NodeGroup spec is that they represent all attributes needed to create a cluster not just part of them. I don't see the need for us to divide them out again with "versioned" and "unversioned" that will require looking at the cluster db entry and the template one. Everything needed for the cluster should be in the cluster db entry. The only time the template entry would be needed is for update/upgrade scenarios if the template changed and the user wanted to update/upgrade.

I'm unsure of what all this extra complexity gives us. It will be difficult to explain what attributes are "versioned" and which ones are not. That list could also change over time as well which means cluster/templates created prior to a change could have an attribute that was unversioned before but versioned later.

I'm unclear how the current proposed solution doesn't meet the requirements. My opinion is that the versioning should be simple with as minimal amount of changes to the api that operators are already using.  

I'm also a little confused at what the actual issue is we are discussing Hongbin(not your fault, there is so much in this thread now). Just want to make sure I'm addressing the correct problem. Before the problem was with a race condition, is that still the issue? If not, what is the issue we are trying to solve that the proposed spec doesn't meet?'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-21 20:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> @hongbin
 > 
 > This seems very complicated to me. Why would we break up versioned
 > vs unversioned attributes? This makes extra work for the operator
 > creating the templates.  It also adds a lot more to the api
 > commands. The proposed way doesn't really add any new commands or a
 > lot of extra flags.  It just simply adds versioning through the
 > current commands.

 > and cluster worked before in that they had different attributes.
 > The new design of Templates in the NodeGroup spec is that they
 > represent all attributes needed to create a cluster not just part
 > of them. I don't see the need for us to divide them out again with
 > "versioned" and "unversioned" that will require looking at the
 > cluster db entry and the template one. Everything needed for the
 > cluster should be in the cluster db entry. The only time the
 > template entry would be needed is for update/upgrade scenarios if
 > the template changed and the user wanted to update/upgrade.
 > 
 > I'm unsure of what all this extra complexity gives us. It will be
 > difficult to explain what attributes are "versioned" and which ones
 > are not. That list could also change over time as well which means
 > cluster/templates created prior to a change could have an attribute
 > that was unversioned before but versioned later.
 > 
 > I'm unclear how the current proposed solution doesn't meet the
 > requirements. My opinion is that the versioning should be simple
 > with as minimal amount of changes to the api that operators are
 > already using.
 > 
 > I'm also a little confused at what the actual issue is we are
 > discussing Hongbin(not your fault, there is so much in this thread
 > now). Just want to make sure I'm addressing the correct problem.
 > Before the problem was with a race condition, is that still the
 > issue? If not, what is the issue we are trying to solve that the
 > proposed spec doesn't meet?

There are two issues I am trying to solve.
* A data consistency problem that I raised in before.
* An over-versioning problem of your proposal.

For the data consistency problem, I already gave an example. When a user issues a cluster-upgrade, it resets the cluster to a factory setting. You proposed to solve this problem by ignoring the same attributes (i.e. node_count) when doing a upgrade. My amendment is just an extension of what you suggested: mark attributes (i.e. node_count) as unversioned attributes so a cluster upgrade won't touch these attributes.

For the template over-versioning problem, I saw you proposed to increment the template version of an update of any attribute. This is unnecessary. Here is an example:

* magnum cluster-template-create --node-count=1 --master-count=1 --flavor=m1.small --key=key1 --coe=atomic_v1 # version 1
* magnum cluster-template-update --node-count=2 # version 2
* magnum cluster-template-update --master-count=3 # version 3
* magnum cluster-template-update --flavor=m1.large # version 4
* magnum cluster-template-update --key=key2 # version 5
* magnum cluster-template update --coe=atomic_v2 # version 6

There are too many versions there. The large amount of template version will soon become untraceable from operators. To solve the problem, operators should be able to specify the list of attributes they want to version:

* magnum cluster-template-create --node-count=1 --master-count=1 --flavor=m1.small --key=key1 --coe=atomic_v1 --versioned-attributes=coe # version 1
* magnum cluster-template-update --node-count=2 # version 1
* magnum cluster-template-update --master-count=3 # version 1
* magnum cluster-template-update --flavor=m1.large # version 1
* magnum cluster-template-update --key=key2 # version 1
* magnum cluster-template update --coe=atomic_v2 # version 2'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-21 21:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

Thank you for clarifying.

* Data consistency problem.  

In my opinion this one is not a versioning issue but an issue with "update" and "upgrade" commands that needs to be worked out.  In the use cases they are always mutually exclusive with the attributes they update.  Upgrade is targeted at coe-version and Update is targeted at the more customized attributes like node counts, names, keys, etc...(Things that are likely going to be different between clusters even if based on the same template). If upgrade will be able to change any attribute then why have "upgrade" as a separate command from "update". If we combine them into one command then I agree with you Hongbin, there should be something to indicate what can be versioned to be updated and what can't.  My proposal is that division is done through the upgrade and update commands and not by dividing the attributes in the database with additional rules and flags.  This seems to be overkill to me for very few attributes that can actually be upgraded or updated.

* An over-versioning problem of your proposal.

I don't agree with this.  A version is any change to the template. Otherwise it gets very complicated to know what matters and what doesn't. I get that this adds flexibility but it adds more room for confusion and mistakes by operators. If a template is created the operator has to keep track of what is or isn't "versioned". They might mean for a new version to get created but it doesn't because they forgot to add that attribute to the versioned attributes when the template was created.  The person updating the template might not be the person who created the template. It also is deceiving to users that the clustertemplate referenced might still show v1 even though it might have change dramatically since it was created.  I like the idea of flexibility but I think this will just cause confusion.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-21 23:32:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> Thank you for clarifying.
 > 
 > * Data consistency problem.
 > 
 > In my opinion this one is not a versioning issue but an issue with
 > "update" and "upgrade" commands that needs to be worked out.  In
 > the use cases they are always mutually exclusive with the
 > attributes they update.  Upgrade is targeted at coe-version and
 > Update is targeted at the more customized attributes like node
 > counts, names, keys, etc...(Things that are likely going to be
 > different between clusters even if based on the same template). If
 > upgrade will be able to change any attribute then why have
 > "upgrade" as a separate command from "update". If we combine them
 > into one command then I agree with you Hongbin, there should be
 > something to indicate what can be versioned to be updated and what
 > can't.  My proposal is that division is done through the upgrade
 > and update commands and not by dividing the attributes in the
 > database with additional rules and flags.  This seems to be
 > overkill to me for very few attributes that can actually be
 > upgraded or updated.

I agree there are actually two set of attributes: i) version attributes that are upgradable, ii) customized attributes that are used for updatable and overridable. If there is no clear cut of these two set of attributes, it will cause a lot of confusions for both end-users, operators, and developers. The boundary of these two set of attributes are very clear. I failed to see why we mixed these two set of attributes into a single data model. The problem is not about how many commands use how many specific attributes. The problem is how to communicate the differences of these two set of attributes to everyone.

 > 
 > * An over-versioning problem of your proposal.
 > 
 > I don't agree with this.  A version is any change to the template.
 > Otherwise it gets very complicated to know what matters and what
 > doesn't. I get that this adds flexibility but it adds more room for
 > confusion and mistakes by operators. If a template is created the
 > operator has to keep track of what is or isn't "versioned". They
 > might mean for a new version to get created but it doesn't because
 > they forgot to add that attribute to the versioned attributes when
 > the template was created.  The person updating the template might
 > not be the person who created the template. It also is deceiving to
 > users that the clustertemplate referenced might still show v1 even
 > though it might have change dramatically since it was created.  I
 > like the idea of flexibility but I think this will just cause
 > confusion.

I think what you said is just a specific use case, and there are other use cases that are out there. As an example, operators want to keep track of the set of clusters that are of a specific COE version, which is the set of clusters they want to patch. If we increment the version on updating every attributes, there will be a large amount of versions out there and things become untrackable. This feature won't have value anymore.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-22 00:02:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

 > version, which is the set of clusters they want to patch. If we
 > increment the version on updating every attributes, there will be a
 > large amount of versions out there and things become untrackable.
 > This feature won't have value anymore.

However, I think you gave a valid argument about why versioning every attributes is a best practice. My suggestion is to have Magnum to version every attributes by default, but allows operators to tune the list.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-22 00:40:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

I think the most ambiguity of this spec is that it proposed to use cluster template for several things:
* Use cluster template as a template to create a cluster
* Use to upgrade to the latest COE version.
* Use to track changes of every cluster attributes.
* Use to track changes of every COE versions.

As long as everything is mixing together, things will become very confusing, and hard to verify the correctness of each operation.'}, {'account_id': 9995, 'date': '2016-11-22 10:11:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> I think the most ambiguity of this spec is that it proposed to use
 > cluster template for several things:
 > * Use cluster template as a template to create a cluster
 > * Use to upgrade to the latest COE version.
 > * Use to track changes of every cluster attributes.
 > * Use to track changes of every COE versions.
 > 
 > As long as everything is mixing together, things will become very
 > confusing, and hard to verify the correctness of each operation.

If we consider the coe_version as simply an additional attribute of the cluster, then the list above could be:
* create cluster from cluster template (from the latest version)
* upgrade cluster to the latest cluster template version

I doubt we'll sort out all issues in the first go. We could instead decide to go with the simpler option already described in the spec, and iterate from there when people start using it."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-22 15:57:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Let's clear this up as I think the comments are now longer then the spec itself.  So many other ideas are being brought in. They are all good points but lets get back to what the spec is about.

@Hongbing, you mention the spec says the following: 
* Use cluster template as a template to create a cluster
* Use to upgrade to the latest COE version.
* Use to track changes of every cluster attributes.
* Use to track changes of every COE versions.


This is not correct. 

*User cluster template as a template to create a cluster. - This is not part of this spec. That is the part of the NodeGroup spec and the discussions that took place at midcycle and summit. This spec just takes that into account. Please put feedback on that here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/352734/ You can also see feedback there in the comments from CERN on operator uses and needs for versioning that triggered this spec.

* Use to upgrade to the latest COE version - This is proposed in the Upgrade spec: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/392193/ 

* Use to track changes of every cluster attributes. -- This is not correct. This spec only provides versioning for ClusterTemplate attribute changes.  It does not intend to track the changes of Cluster attributes.  It does not propose any tracking on Clusters. The information from the template version can be used to compare with Clusters for features like Upgrades, but the way that is done is not outlined in this spec.

* Use to track changes of every COE versions -- Again, this is not the purpose of this spec.  coe_version is one of the attributes within a ClusterTemplate so any changes to the version within a ClusterTemplate will be versioned.  That could be used by features like Upgrade to determine an upgrade path, but that is part of the upgrade spec not this one.


So what is this spec about?

* Add a simple versioning scheme to Templates(both Cluster and NodeGroup).

* Allow users(specifically operators) to track changes that have been made to a ClusterTemplate. Making sure that the data for each version that has been used to create a Cluster is available. Having this data allows for the future addition of features like Upgrade that can use this information to compare an existing Cluster created from a template to the latest version of that template.

This spec does not add any additional commands around templates. It uses the existing template commands and adds versioning to them. The only API changes are 2 additional flags around list and show to enable viewing different template versions.  Any additional commands around features such as cluster-create using templates or the future upgrade feature are not part of this spec. They have their own specs.

I know there are a lot of open specs right now and they overlap a lot in the interactions between them.  The concerns here related to the other specs are valid, but i wanted to make clear that this spec is not trying to solve the new v2 api in NodeGroup or the features of the new upgrade feature.  This spec is targeted on just adding versioning to ClusterTemplates and NodeGroupTemplates."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-22 18:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

I think we might need to setup sometime to have a team discussion on the major specs that are out there and how they interconnect.  I think this might help get a better picture of how this spec, NodeGroup(v2 API), Upgrade, and flatten attributes are related to make sure we are not missing something like the important issues that Hongbin brought up in this review.'}, {'account_id': 9591, 'date': '2016-11-22 23:23:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

I would like to make some general observations: 

(1) When we make change to a cluster, some attributes will be updated. Technically all such change operations can be grouped behind the cluster-update command, but in practice, it's probably more desirable to break them up into lifecycle operations such as cluster-upgrade, cluster-scale, etc.   I think there is general consensus in this direction.  These lifecycle operations would update their particular cluster attributes (e.g. COE version), so it would make sense to disallow changing these attributes directly through cluster-update.  As we add more lifecycle operations, we would make the adjustment accordingly.  

(2) We are going through some major expansion of Magnum capabilities and with these, some major internal redesign.  It's good to break up the redesign into separate specs so they are more manageable, but the risk is that within each spec, it can be confusing to understand the inter-related scope and we might miss gaps that will become hard to fix later.   I would agree with Jayen's suggestion to have a high level discussion to pull together the big picture and draw up a clear line between the specs."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-22 23:41:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

I agree this spec needs more discussion, because it lays down the basic for all the life-cycle operations. If we get the data model wrong at the beginning, it will be more expensive to recover. We definitely need to involve the whole team to collaborate the design.'}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-11-29 17:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/ocata-magnum-next-api

Added data structure combined with other specs. Also information on how the specs are related'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-30 03:42:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

As showed in the etherpad, this spec proposed to put all attributes into a single table:

cluster_attributes:
 - id (new)
 - apiserver_port
 - create_timeout
 - discovery_url
 - node_count
 - master_count
 - keypair_id
 - labels
 - external_network_id
 - fixed_network
 - fixed_subnet
 - network_driver
 - volume_driver
 - dns_nameserver
 - coe
 - http_proxy
 - https_proxy
 - no_proxy
 - registry_enabled
 - tls_disabled
 - insecure_registry
 - master_lb_enabled
 - floating_ip_enabled
 - image_id
 - flavor_id
 - docker_volume_size
 - docker_storage_driver
 - cluster_distro
 - server_type
 - master_flavor_id

I don't think this is a good idea, because it makes cluster-upgrade difficult to understand and implement. I would argue that cluster template is not the right handle to do cluster upgrade because most of the attributes (i.e. node_count) are actually not upgraded.

I would suggest to leave cluster template as is and introduce another abstraction (i.e. cluster_driver) to handle upgrade. This requires to separate attributes into two tables:

cluster_attributes:
 - id (new)
 - apiserver_port
 - create_timeout
 - discovery_url
 - node_count
 - master_count
 - keypair_id
 - labels
 - external_network_id
 - fixed_network

 - tls_disabled

 - master_lb_enabled
 - floating_ip_enabled
 - flavor_id
 - docker_volume_size
 - docker_storage_driver
 - master_flavor_id
 
cluster_driver_attributes:
 - coe
 - cluster_distro
 - server_type
 - image_id

This will correctly model a cluster upgrade, since a cluster upgrade will update the cluster_driver_attributes and all cluster_attributes are left unchanged."}, {'account_id': 9995, 'date': '2016-11-30 09:32:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

It is needed to correctly model the problem sets (i.e. update, upgrade, etc.).

If what you want is just versioning the template, you can simply add an attribute "version" to the cluster_template table. Then, all the complexity of versioning is eliminated.

This is the complication. Everyone need to figure out:

* the details of template version x
* the details of template version y
* the difference between template version x and template version y.
* which attributes matter for what (i.e. update, upgrade).
* what is actually upgraded
* what is actually not upgraded

This is a significant overhead.

 > not, is up to the command itself.  Update will look at different
 > attributes in the difference. Other life cycle commands like Ton
 > suggested might care about the difference of other attributes.  By
 > making template versioning simple and for all attributes this

 > separating our data structures into attributes that are specific to
 > commands then we will have to constantly change our data structures
 > any time our commands change.

No, I proposed to separate data structure between upgrade and the rest of the commands. I think we all agreed that upgrade is special. I guess that is why you proposed to use template to upgrade (all the rest of operations are not using a template). If you think upgrade is the same as the rest of operations, then you can drop the reference between cluster and cluster template and upgrade all the attributes in cluster.

> This is the complication. Everyone need to figure out:
 > 
 > * the details of template version x
 > * the details of template version y
 > * the difference between template version x and template version y.
 > * which attributes matter for what (i.e. update, upgrade).
 > * what is actually upgraded
 > * what is actually not upgraded
 > 
 > This is a significant overhead.

I don't agree that is significant overhead.  Let's take the example of upgrade:

Cluster A was created with ClusterTemplate X v1.

ClusterTemplate was updated to change coe_version=1.2. So it is now ClusterTemplate v2.

User performs cluster-upgrade ClusterA.

- cluster-upgrade steps internally

* get cluster entry for ClusterA attributes

* based on ClusterA ClusterTemplate attribute get the latest clustertemplateversion entry for that Template.

* determine the difference for the attributes that matter( in this case just coe-version)

* pass difference to driver upgrade command

This seems very straight forward. It is a simple compare and allows the command to determine what attributes matter. Why push that complexity into the data model structure?  The above steps would be the same for update just caring about different attributes. All the info is there for both commands. This would also allow the flexibility for even different drivers to care about different attributes.  What if one driver could update an attribute but another couldn't? Would that attribute be considered upgradable for all or not? By not limiting what attributes matter in the data structure we can pass all the difference down to the driver and it can determine what is valid and not valid for update.

In general, my opinion is to keep the decisions of what each attribute can and can't do within commands like upgrade, update, and life cycle operations outside of the data structure.

Hongbin, i think we have both made our points on this and just have different views. I understand why you want to have the data structure match the functionality of some of the commands. I think there are good pros for doing that. And if that is what the team decides I'll back it.  I think we need feedback from the rest of the team now."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-11-30 19:12:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> (1 comment)

@ricardo, is node_count really not useful at all in a template? I'd think having the template have for example master_node_count of 1 and minion_node_count 2 as a default would be useful. The user could always override that on creation, but if they didn't as just used the template to create a cluster they would at least get a valid working cluster."}, {'account_id': 9995, 'date': '2016-12-01 07:51:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> > (1 comment)
 > 
 > @ricardo, is node_count really not useful at all in a template? I'd
 > think having the template have for example master_node_count of 1
 > and minion_node_count 2 as a default would be useful. The user
 > could always override that on creation, but if they didn't as just
 > used the template to create a cluster they would at least get a
 > valid working cluster.

In our case if it's there we would set it to something conservative (like a low value) and it quickly gets changed, if not at creation already (which is what we tell people to do). One could imagine an operator offering templates of pre-defined sizes (like nova flavors), but given the size of the cluster is supposed to be dynamic i feel it  belongs to the cluster instance.

For the master_node_count right now we plan to offer templates for non-HA (single master), and HA (multi-master, spread across different AZs when we get node groups) setups, very few users if any will need to tune this. So it seems to be a property of the template in this case."}, {'account_id': 9591, 'date': '2016-12-02 18:01:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

From Ricardo and Spyros' description of their users' need, I see two general patterns:  

(1) Users who just need to run their containers and don't want to deal with the infrastructure, so they want the cloud operator to handle the infrastructure for them, including upgrade, etc.  For this group, it would make sense for the operator to manage a set of public templates that the users would use for all lifecycle operations.

(2) Users who want to fine tune and tweak their cluster.  They would want to manage the cluster attributes themselves.

I think we agree on the view that the template is just a collection of attributes.  Based on (1), the template is more than a convenience for users;  it's a service from the operator that users rely on.  
So far we are proposing to use template only for cluster-create. The reason I believe is to decouple the cluster attributes from the template.  This forces cluster-upgrade to become a special case.

To avoid the special case and perhaps make it easier for users to reason about Magnum operations, one approach we can take is to generalize further and allow a template to be used for any lifecycle operation, not just cluster-upgrade.  Then to the users, the template being used is again just a collection of attributes to be compared against the current cluster attributes.  All the validation will still need to be done. 
A lifecycle operation then can specify a few parameters, or a template.  If no template is specified, the latest version of the template from the cluster-create would be used.  The code for the operation would just use the parameters it cares about and ignore the rest.

In practice, I would think that only a few relevant attributes would be changed at a time in each template version, not a wholesale change.

If this seems like a reasonable approach, then this may help with deciding the internal DB structure in the implementation."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-12-02 18:29:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> From Ricardo and Spyros' description of their users' need, I see
 > two general patterns:
 > 
 > (1) Users who just need to run their containers and don't want to
 > deal with the infrastructure, so they want the cloud operator to
 > handle the infrastructure for them, including upgrade, etc.  For
 > this group, it would make sense for the operator to manage a set of
 > public templates that the users would use for all lifecycle
 > operations.
 > 
 > (2) Users who want to fine tune and tweak their cluster.  They
 > would want to manage the cluster attributes themselves.
 > 
 > I think we agree on the view that the template is just a collection
 > of attributes.  Based on (1), the template is more than a
 > convenience for users;  it's a service from the operator that users
 > rely on.
 > So far we are proposing to use template only for cluster-create.
 > The reason I believe is to decouple the cluster attributes from the
 > template.  This forces cluster-upgrade to become a special case.
 > 
 > To avoid the special case and perhaps make it easier for users to
 > reason about Magnum operations, one approach we can take is to
 > generalize further and allow a template to be used for any
 > lifecycle operation, not just cluster-upgrade.  Then to the users,
 > the template being used is again just a collection of attributes to
 > be compared against the current cluster attributes.  All the
 > validation will still need to be done.
 > A lifecycle operation then can specify a few parameters, or a
 > template.  If no template is specified, the latest version of the
 > template from the cluster-create would be used.  The code for the
 > operation would just use the parameters it cares about and ignore
 > the rest.
 > 
 > In practice, I would think that only a few relevant attributes
 > would be changed at a time in each template version, not a
 > wholesale change.
 > 
 > If this seems like a reasonable approach, then this may help with
 > deciding the internal DB structure in the implementation.

+1 Ton, I think your suggestion on further generalizing templates for all the commands is a good one. That is how I pictured templates being used for any command.

What was approved in the flatten attributes spec was to make templates and specifically ClusterTemplate a resource that is more for operators and convenience then something required for creating clusters.First in the data structures and then in v2 api.  I was under the impression that since that spec was approved and merged that it was the direction we were going. This spec is based on adding versioning on top of that data structure.

I think over time all the lifecycle operations could have options that use or don't use templates.  There are tons of enhancements that could be made to the commands for operators and users in general in the future using the templates and versions.

I do agree that upgrade is a special and complicated case. To me that is more of a reason to keep that complexity in the command code and not in the data structure. I think it will take sometime to settle on what upgrade can and can't do for each of the drivers."}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2016-12-02 19:12:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> From Ricardo and Spyros' description of their users' need, I see
 > two general patterns:
 > 
 > (1) Users who just need to run their containers and don't want to
 > deal with the infrastructure, so they want the cloud operator to
 > handle the infrastructure for them, including upgrade, etc.  For
 > this group, it would make sense for the operator to manage a set of
 > public templates that the users would use for all lifecycle
 > operations.
 > 
 > (2) Users who want to fine tune and tweak their cluster.  They
 > would want to manage the cluster attributes themselves.

@Ton, this is an insightful observation. Personally, I don't like to use cluster_template for both (1) and (2). This will cause a lot of confusion and make life-cycle operation (i.e. upgrade) difficulty to understand from outside. My proposal is to separate (1) and (2) into two abstractions. There are several options to do this:

* (1) cluster_driver, (2) cluster_template
* (1) cluster_version, (2) cluster_template
* (1) cluster_template, (2) cluster_parameter
* (1) cluster_template, (2) cluster_configuration
* ...

I wholeheartedly disagree to overload cluster_template to make it solve both (1) and (2).

 > 
 > I think we agree on the view that the template is just a collection
 > of attributes.  Based on (1), the template is more than a
 > convenience for users;  it's a service from the operator that users
 > rely on.
 > So far we are proposing to use template only for cluster-create.
 > The reason I believe is to decouple the cluster attributes from the
 > template.  This forces cluster-upgrade to become a special case.
 > 
 > To avoid the special case and perhaps make it easier for users to
 > reason about Magnum operations, one approach we can take is to
 > generalize further and allow a template to be used for any
 > lifecycle operation, not just cluster-upgrade.  Then to the users,
 > the template being used is again just a collection of attributes to
 > be compared against the current cluster attributes.  All the
 > validation will still need to be done.
 > A lifecycle operation then can specify a few parameters, or a
 > template.  If no template is specified, the latest version of the
 > template from the cluster-create would be used.  The code for the
 > operation would just use the parameters it cares about and ignore
 > the rest.

I think this is an alternative approach that we can discuss it further. From my point of view, it seems to be more clear if we move all life-cycle operations to cluster_template. If we decide to do this, the data model needs to be re-designed:

* The cluster attributes don't need to be copied from cluster_template to cluster anymore, since all operations can be performed on cluster_template.
* We need to figure out the mapping between cluster_template and cluster (i.e. one-to-one mapping, or one-to-many mapping). In either case, the design of data model could be very different.

 > 
 > In practice, I would think that only a few relevant attributes
 > would be changed at a time in each template version, not a
 > wholesale change.
 > 
 > If this seems like a reasonable approach, then this may help with
 > deciding the internal DB structure in the implementation."}, {'account_id': 13861, 'date': '2016-12-02 19:33:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(17 comments)

Some thought/comments/queries inline. If i missed some discussion just give the reference, sorry for visiting too late.'}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-12-02 19:42:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

> > From Ricardo and Spyros' description of their users' need, I see
 > > two general patterns:
 > >
 > > (1) Users who just need to run their containers and don't want to
 > > deal with the infrastructure, so they want the cloud operator to
 > > handle the infrastructure for them, including upgrade, etc.  For
 > > this group, it would make sense for the operator to manage a set
 > of
 > > public templates that the users would use for all lifecycle
 > > operations.
 > >
 > > (2) Users who want to fine tune and tweak their cluster.  They
 > > would want to manage the cluster attributes themselves.
 > 
 > @Ton, this is an insightful observation. Personally, I don't like
 > to use cluster_template for both (1) and (2). This will cause a lot
 > of confusion and make life-cycle operation (i.e. upgrade)
 > difficulty to understand from outside. My proposal is to separate
 > (1) and (2) into two abstractions. There are several options to do
 > this:
 > 
 > * (1) cluster_driver, (2) cluster_template
 > * (1) cluster_version, (2) cluster_template
 > * (1) cluster_template, (2) cluster_parameter
 > * (1) cluster_template, (2) cluster_configuration
 > * ...
 > 
 > I wholeheartedly disagree to overload cluster_template to make it
 > solve both (1) and (2).
 > 
 > >
 > > I think we agree on the view that the template is just a
 > collection
 > > of attributes.  Based on (1), the template is more than a
 > > convenience for users;  it's a service from the operator that
 > users
 > > rely on.
 > > So far we are proposing to use template only for cluster-create.
 > > The reason I believe is to decouple the cluster attributes from
 > the
 > > template.  This forces cluster-upgrade to become a special case.
 > >
 > > To avoid the special case and perhaps make it easier for users to
 > > reason about Magnum operations, one approach we can take is to
 > > generalize further and allow a template to be used for any
 > > lifecycle operation, not just cluster-upgrade.  Then to the
 > users,
 > > the template being used is again just a collection of attributes
 > to
 > > be compared against the current cluster attributes.  All the
 > > validation will still need to be done.
 > > A lifecycle operation then can specify a few parameters, or a
 > > template.  If no template is specified, the latest version of the
 > > template from the cluster-create would be used.  The code for the
 > > operation would just use the parameters it cares about and ignore
 > > the rest.
 > 
 > I think this is an alternative approach that we can discuss it
 > further. From my point of view, it seems to be more clear if we
 > move all life-cycle operations to cluster_template. If we decide to
 > do this, the data model needs to be re-designed:
 > 
 > * The cluster attributes don't need to be copied from
 > cluster_template to cluster anymore, since all operations can be
 > performed on cluster_template.
 > * We need to figure out the mapping between cluster_template and
 > cluster (i.e. one-to-one mapping, or one-to-many mapping). In
 > either case, the design of data model could be very different.
 > 
 > >
 > > In practice, I would think that only a few relevant attributes
 > > would be changed at a time in each template version, not a
 > > wholesale change.
 > >
 > > If this seems like a reasonable approach, then this may help with
 > > deciding the internal DB structure in the implementation.

@hongbin,
i think the use of template here is where i'm getting confused. I think what you mean is you want to divide cluster attributes into 2 structures: driver attributes and cluster attributes.  This kind of how BayModel and Bay worked before. 2 different sets of attributes with different rules on their use.  The flatten attribute spec changed that so that all attributes are now going to be in one structure.  To me, Template is completely separate from this. A template is just  representation of a set of attributes that can be reused to for cluster operations.  So if we slit the attributes into 2 sets(driver, non-driver) I'd say we would need a driver template and non-driver template.  The template is just an representation of the attributes.  All of discusion here is not about template versioning at all in my opinion, what you are arguing for is a different cluster attribute orginization. The flatten attributes spec changed that and the node group spec is the api spec for it.

No matter what the cluster attribute structure I think having generic templates for user ease is a good idea. I also think that adding versioning to those templates is very useful. This concept will work on top of whatever structure is decided for cluster attributes. It could be one template or multiple.  The current plan is ClusterTemplates and NodeGroupTemplates to represent all the attributes needed in a cluster.  If we need/want to add ClusterDriver attribute division, then we would add a ClusterDriverTemplate as well.  In all cases, the template versioning laid out here should provide the way to control the versioning of those templates. That is why I refer to templates in the spec and not just ClusterTemplates. It is designed for any template.

On a side note, I think we made a mistake by calling the current BayModel a ClusterTemplate before we changed how it was used. A template should never have different attributes from the object it is the template of. That has lead to a lot of confusion."}, {'account_id': 21469, 'date': '2016-12-02 20:27:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

approach that reduces the privileges granted to trustee users
to the minimum required. Summary:

* Allow authenticated users in Magnum domain to perform
  certificate operations without any roles. This way a trust
  is unneccessary for these operations.

  Cinder API.

commit_message:
Updated spec for trusts

This commit updates the spec for trustee users with an
approach that reduces the privileges granted to trustee users
to the minimum required. Summary:

* Allow authenticated users in Magnum domain to perform
  certificate operations without any roles. This way a trust
  is unneccessary for these operations.
* Only create trust for clusters that use Rexray to access the
  Cinder API or that create their own registry.

Change-Id: Ie8eab5ac3a324a2d0d4dd7756632da456bff2dee

commit_message:
Fix build warning in c codes

There are some build warning observed when building c codes.
It is not critical as they are still warning, but it would be
better to avoid these warning if possible.

Trivial-fix
Change-Id: I5f89fc0defce43984471576025636e172630e733

commit_message:
Move reproducer README file

when trying to use reproducer generator stand standalone, README file is taken
from collect logs.
This change moves it to the create reproducer role, and make it a standard
file, not a template, since it does not use any variable

Change-Id: Ie21f47264680b468ce51a3e1f8305670889ccb41

[{'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2019-06-12 04:45:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2019-08-25 10:43:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

It's done for multinode and there is a patch for ovb, but logs server on rdo infra doesn't work well with that."}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2019-08-25 12:30:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> It's done for multinode and there is a patch for ovb, but logs
 > server on rdo infra doesn't work well with that.

IIUC, http://logs.rdoproject.org doesn't have the middleware installed, but https://logs.rdoproject.org does render the ara-report directory properly.

Though, opendev.org uses swift and needs ara html files. I'll re-propose this change for rdo base job."}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2019-08-25 12:30:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

opendev.org uses swift and needs ara html files'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-12 04:45:52.000000000', 'message': "tripleo-ci-base: disable ara generate html

This change disables the ara html generation as it doesn't seems to work.
Instead the ansible-role-collect-logs will create ara-report directory
that should be served by the ara middleware.

Change-Id: Ic49bc509583f87f391fe9cc7788ecb77c5bb09e5
"}]
commit_message:
tripleo-ci-base: disable ara generate html

This change disables the ara html generation as it doesn't seems to work.
Instead the ansible-role-collect-logs will create ara-report directory
that should be served by the ara middleware.

Change-Id: Ic49bc509583f87f391fe9cc7788ecb77c5bb09e5

commit_message:
Support backup filtering

To get all the backups of an instance:

    openstack database backup list --instance-id <instance-id>

Admin user gets backups of all the projects:

    openstack database backup list --all-projects

Story: #2006433
Task: #36346
Change-Id: I871d1ffa27805158024e8ecbe1dceae725c4deac
